item.title: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3667) to amend the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act to designate a segment of the Missisquoi and Trout Rivers in the State of Vermont for study for potential addition to the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 223 - 190 (Roll no. 577). (text: CR H7963)

item.text: Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 1419, H. Res. 1399 is laid on the table.
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 258.
The resolution provides for House proceedings.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-816, by Mr. McGovern.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-816, by Mr. McGovern.

summary.text:
Provides that, when the House adjourns pursuant to this resolution on any legislative day between August 1 and September 4, 2008, it shall stand adjourned until 11 a.m. on the third constitutional day thereafter.

Authorizes the Speaker to appoint Members to perform the duties (Speaker pro tempore) of the Chair during such period.

Authorizes the Speaker, on each such day, to dispense with legislative business.

Considers the Journal of the proceedings of the previous day as approved.

Provides that, unless the Speaker determines otherwise, after the third daily order of business under Rule XIV (Order and Priority of Business) and any proceedings that may be sought under Rule XV, the House shall stand adjourned.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

bill.title: Providing for proceedings during the period from August 1, 2008, through September 4, 2008.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
